form.ocrd: OCR-D Metadata form for ground truth data

title.ocrdetail: Detailed information about the OCR model trained with the GT

step1.title: Fill the form
step1.desc: Follow the examples and note that you can always manually modify the output. This form only helps you structure the description and ensure that every item is documented.

gt.title: Type of Ground Truth
gt.desc:
document GT
The Ground Truth contains annotated and complete documents. A complete document is, for example, a book or an article. Annotations of the text and document structure (for example: headings, paragraphs, footnotes) have been made.
structure GT
The ground truth contains annotated document parts such as individual pages or paragraphs. Exclusively annotation of the document structure (for example: headings, paragraphs, footnotes) has been done.
structure and text GT
Ground truth contains annotated document parts such as individual pages or paragraphs. Annotations of the text and document structure (for example: headings, paragraphs, footnotes) have been made.
line GT
The ground truth contains annotated document lines only. Annotations of the text as well as the line have been made.

level.title: Transcription level
level.desc:
An overview of the transcription levels can be found at GT-Guidelines.

The mixed level contains transcriptions that correspond to several levels. There is no compatibility between the levels, see for example hyphenation.

To assess the transcription level, please read the GT-Guidelines

env.title: Training environment
env.desc: The training environment specifies the software with which the OCR model was created or trained, e.g. tesseract [version].

input.src: Link to the source or a catalog description

field.software: Software use to produce the data

year.info: For centuries, please prefer the use of 1200 when a dataset starts in the 13th century and 1299 when it ends in the 13th century. Dates do not need to be precise.

field.std_info: This is a non-exhaustive selection of license options.

project.name: Project's name (if different from the repository/dataset's one)

field.software_placeholder: You can use the following buttons to populate the field.

guidelines.label: Transcription guidelines
guidelines.info: Guidelines used to transcribe the resources (normalization, resolution of abbreviation, correction of mispelling, etc.)

cff.info: CITATION.cf files allow for generating quick APA citations or Bibtex ones on github for example. See:

field.apa: We prefer APA references, which can look like the following Allport, G. W. (1930–1967). Correspondence. Gordon W. Allport Papers (HUG 4118.10), Harvard University Archives, Cambridge, MA, United States., see APA Style, but simpler formats are okay too. The link or the APA reference are sufficient but you can provide both.

form.head: Fields followed by a * are the only ones required.

scripts.label: Font/Writing system
scripts.helper: To ease data entry, default values are already selected. Just click on it to deselect the one you don't want.

languages.label: Language(s)
languages.helper: To ease data entry, default values are already selected. Just click on it to deselect the one you don't want.

download.text3: A METADATA.yml file is created in your repository. You can now paste into the metadata created.
download.text2: to the clipboard and click on this

desc.main:
HTR-United is a Github organization without any other form of legal personality. It aims at gathering HTR/OCR models for and transcriptions of all periods and style of writing, mostly but not exclusively in French.
It was born from the mere necessity -for projects- to possess potentiel ground truth to rapidly train models on smaller corpora.

footer.team: Who are the people behind HTR-United?
